TELEGRAPHIC.
THE VERY LATEST NEWS BY WIRE
(By Special Telegraph.)
OTTAWA, Feb. 27.—Mr. Fisher, one of the United States' West delegates, leaves for Prince Albert today. He expects to arrive here before the 15th February, 1886, otherwise they will be placed in the hands of the Attorney General of the Saskatchewan Court of Law here. If not convenient to meet me at the railway station, I am sure that I should have seen you there.

Parties having accounts against me will please render them to myself.

A. E. PORTER.
Prince Albert, Jan. 12, 1886.

DRESSMAKING
I WILL SELL
HATS
AND ALL
WOOLEN GOODS!
AT VERY LOW RATES.
Call and get prices.
Miss MAUIRE,
CAMPBELL'S BLOCK.

NOTICE!
Mr. Hughes, M.M.C., having been authorized by the Lieutenant Governor to expend a certain sum of money on the Main Trail between Prince Albert and Battleford, would be glad to receive all necessary particulars on application, and to receive tenders for the work. Mr. Hughes has also a small amount available from the funds voted by the Crown and which can now be used to his advantage. Applications to both sums should be made at once.

J. C. MacKenzie has thus far received the first installment of his spring Books and Shoes. Call and see them, and will send by mail.

We have heard through Mr. G. S. Davison, of the H. B. Co., that the Winnipeg & Western Transportation Co. will be able to reduce their prices for spring 1886. Prince Albert, general merchandise, per 100 lbs., 40¢; Books, 50¢; Fish, 15¢.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.
Gathered by our Reporters.

Elegant Parlour at Clark's Drug Store.
The new few weeks business has been very briskly.

The skating race on the Saskatche-
wan river will take place on Monday, the 11th inst.

The Prince Albert Hockey Team has been doing its best, and is very much improved in appearance.

Follow a Syrup of Lemon, Sour's Eau-
de-Cologne, and a Cup of Liver Oil at Clark's Drug Store.

Mr. J. F. Small, the popular teacher at our Public School, returned from South Dakota, where he studied the Sioux Indians.

The interest in our Town Parliament seems to have flattened out on about the same rate as taken in our Town Council.

Col. Spratt and party left for Carlton on Wednesday last for the purpose of purchasing a horse for the next season. They will be absent about four months.

Mr. T. J. Agnew arrived home yesterday by way of an extended tour during which he visited, among other places, his old home in the Channel Islands.

As will appear by their advertisements, Mr. Chamberlain & Co. are selling the balance of their winter goods at reduced prices.

Their new spring stock has been shipped from Winnipeg.

There was a big crowd at Mr. Irving's, N.W.M.P., last night giving a ball next Monday evening to the citizens. A huge number of in-
vitations were sent out, and every eligible man is expected.

We are pleased to hear that Mr. J. M. Lee, the popular Indian Agent, has been appointed to the position of Inspector of Indian Agencies. This is undoubtedly a well-deserved promotion.

The single hand curling match for the medal presented by the Hon. L. Clarke was concluded this afternoon. The last two matches were played by Messrs. Ross and Brown. Mayor McKay won by a few points, and holds the medal till next year.

We regret to have announce the death of an old and esteemed settler of the parish of St. Catharine's, Mr. Henry Murray, who died last week. His funeral on the last day was a large affair.

The members of the Town Band turned out on Wednesday evening, and drove to the residence of Mr. Belanger, Esq., to hear a string of songs. Mr. Belanger received the boys in his own hospitable manner, and a few hours were spent in speeches, songs, etc.

The members of the Argyle Curling and Shooting Club held their first meeting last night at the Argyle Club. We hope to see a large turn out of the citizens from both ends of the town. The band played some music and danced a sweet music during the evening.

We call the attention to Mr. Hughes' notice in another column. We congratulate our member on his success in obtaining a grant from the Dominion government for the use of our school, which are badly in need of it. We believe this grant is about the first indication we have had of any movement toward the funds at the disposal of the Lieut. Governor to this part of the country, although large grants have been made to the schools in the more populated districts.

A game of points was played this evening between the Saskatche-
wan Curling Club and the Calgary club. The ice was in bad shape, and the game was not made.

The game was played by Mr. J. F. Pringle, who scored fifteen points. The medal was then played for by the winners of the previous year, Mr. J. F. Pringle and Mr. Col. Spratt (last year's winner being absent), and resulted in favor of Mr. J. F. Pringle, who is now the holder of the Calgary medal played for in the North West.
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

J. D. MAVEETY

PRINCE ALBERT N.W.T.

PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

SUNDAY CHURCH SERVICES

ST. MARY'S

ST. PAUL'S

ST. JOHN'S

ST. ANDREW'S

ST. CATHERINE'S

FRIDAY, MARCH 5, 1866

N. W. C. DELEGATES

MESSRS. W. D. D. PERLEY OF WELLSLEY, J. ROSS OF MOOSE JAW, AND DR. J. T. WILSON OF EDWARDSVILLE, WERE APPOINTED TO REPRESENT THE NORTH WEST COUNCIL TO GO TO OTTAWA AND TO SUBMIT TO THE DOMINION GOVERNMENT ON BEHALF OF THE PEOPLE OF THE NORTH WEST TERRITORIES THE FOLLOWING BILL FOR THE YEAR 1866:

That the Council have power to incorporate companies having purely territorial objects, the immediate settlement of old settler's claims, and the sale of land.

That the Government should use its influence to have the freight rates on the Canadian Pacific Railway reduced, especially on lumber from British Columbia.

That no measures be made to settle the wood or fuel, and that each homesteader be allowed 4,000 local feet of building timber on a five year permit.

The early improvement of the North Saskatchewan.

The granting of the right of habitation to the North West.

The opening for settlement of ceded lands.

A Special Court of Appeal.

The construction of a trail to Peace River.

Representation in the Senate and House of Commons.

The establishment of the Territorial road of land transport.

The right to enter a pre-emption as a second homestead.

The encouragement of railways through the territories.

That the same will be given equal to the duty now imposed on agricultural implements and lumber.

That the odd-numbered sections should be opened for settlement.

That measures be taken by Parliament to provide a system of government in the North-West should be agreed in the North-West Council, as the representatives of the people.

The early and rapid construction of the Hudson's Bay Railway.

The immediate appointment of a commission to settle outstanding half-breed claims.

The prompt settlement of claims for compensation for railway losses, and the payment of settlers and merchants who furnished supplies to the troops in good faith.

The appointment of residents of the Territories to positions of trust and responsibility in the Territories.

That all food supplies for the Mounted Police and Indians be purchased in the Territories.

The recognition of the services of the Mounted Police and the Prince Albert and Battleford special forces in a manner similar to the volunteer force.

The delegation arrived in Ottawa on the 17th ult., and felt satisfied with the reception they received. It is expected that the provisions of the Bill of Rights will be granted.

The territories will receive five representatives in the House of Commons and two in the Senate; Alberta being represented by two members, while one will be given one, Saskatchewan with 8,000 population, one, and Assiniboina with 15,000, two.

The St. Paul Pioneer Press says Donald Grant, the railroad contractor left St. Paul last evening for the South. He admits that he and Roary McLennan have contracted with the Canadian Pacific Company to build the first part of that line, and hopes to start work early in the ensuing spring. Mr. Grant said he had full faith that the line would make a profit to the proprietors of not only the Canadian Northwest but also get a share of the States' and Territorial business as well.

In laying the matter before the English capitalists, the testimony of the captain of the steamer was most emphatic in what he removed the season's crop product before the close of navigation. Of course, Mr. Grant further said, steamers could not navigate the river after navigation closed, that is, after the ice came down, and that sailing vessels from four to eight months of the year.

The new mill machinery will arrive here next week, and will be installed at once. The new mill machinery will be installed at once.

Mr. Behanger, of the H.R.C., left yesterday morning for the east. He expects to reach Edmonton Monday and then proceed by dog train across the lakes to his home at Cumberland. He expects to return here on the opening of navigation by river boat.

JAMES SINCLAIR

Merchant Tailor

GENTS' FURNISHINGS

SETTLERS' MEETING

A meeting was held at St. Catherine's on the 19th inst., to consider the question of establishing a school in the adjoining parish. Mr. Hughes M.N.W. C., who was present by invitation, addressed the meeting. Mr. Wm. Craig, Secretary. The Rev. Canon Field detailed the steps he had taken in the matter, which were so limited in quantity, that they could not meet anything like a general application for relief. The meeting was unanimous in opinion that the Rev. Canon had done all in his power to meet the case, but that the matter was beyond his control, and ought not to be undertaken. As it was very evident that a large majority of the Half-Breed population of both parties were unable to pay their taxes, a committee was appointed to interview Mr. Adams, the Indian Agent, and the Chairman and Secretary of the Board of Commissioners of the deputation, none of whom are applicants for relief. After a vote of thanks to the Secretary, the meeting adjourned.

In accordance with the above resolution, a committee consisting of Mr. Adams, L.D. and Mr. Pritchard, the relief officer, but although both gentlemen expressed sympathy with them, they stated that they had no power to meet their demands. The deputation then requested Mr. Hughes to forward the facts of the case to His Honour the Lord-Governor.

It appears that about four hundred souls are living in the various parishes, and that at present the Government allowance would only admit of an increase of about twenty-five cents per head, or less than one and three-quarters of an ounce of beef per day per head.

We understand that the English people living partly in the same neighborhood as the Indians, were amongst those detained here last spring at seeding time to garrison this place and were unable to put in their crops. We understand also that the Indians were instructed to be there in order to state that they were led to believe by Brigadier Major Hayter Reid that they would receive rations until next harvest. We have heard this statement from several sources, and should like the subject ventilated, perhaps some of our readers could enlighten us.

QU'APPÉLIE

From the Editor,

Dr. Semple has received instructions to conduct a medical inspection of the adjacent district.

A medical examination is to be held in the creek house on Tuesday next, and we understand that quite a number of persons are likely to appear.

The new mill machinery will arrive here next week, and will be installed at once.

Mr. Behanger, of the H.R.C., left yesterday morning for the east. He expects to reach Edmonton Monday and then proceed by dog train across the lakes to his home at Cumberland. He expects to return here on the opening of navigation by river boat.

JAMES SINCLAIR

Merchant Tailor

GENTS' FURNISHINGS

WAR DECLARED!

W. C. RAMSAY

Would respectfully intimate to his friends and the public generally that he has purchased Thompson Castle, a handsome building, and has renamed it River Street, near J. L. John's hardware store, where he has determined to reside. He charges high prices for his engraving and general blacksmithing. A trial is respectfully solicited.

The Nor West Farmer

To Yield a Generous Return to the Farmer

It is desired, a good deal to bring about this happy state of affairs, and wants the co-operation of every man in the province.

The Nor West Farmer is devoted to the interests and advancement of agriculture, and will give every facility to those who desire to run over with information and news of the latest developments in the world of farming and its branches. It will give every facility to those who desire to run over with information and news of the latest developments in the world of farming and its branches.

The Nor West Farmer Printing and Publishing Co., Ltd.

WINNIPEG MANITOBA

Subscriptions taken at the office of the Prince Albert Times.
NORTH WEST NOTES

FORT MCKEO.

From the Gazette.

A very light fall of snow fell last night past midnight, but making the ground look white. It has all disappeared. There men named Sota, Matson and Simpson have been Trappered. They have not been captured.

The ice is now open at Kipp, and at several other places, where fishing is impossible. At no place is the ice safe to cross on.

We understand that the services of Mr. Chipman, teacher on the Methodist Mission on the Reserve reserve, have been dispensed with.

Construction has been commenced on the Roman Catholic church at Pincher Creek. From the information received it is going to be a very handsome building, and will be a great acquisition to our sisters.

There was a heavy fall of tropical rain on Friday. Somewhere in the neighborhood of 14 inches fell in the rain and hail. The weather will probably continue through several more weeks in a most unseasonable manner. It is going on every day.

For the past week the weather has been very windy, beautifully calm and cool, by day. The weather was warm and the nights hot. There being only one really cold day, viz., Sunday, the maximum of the thermometer during the time specified has been about 30°, while the minimum (Sun) varied from 25° to 28°.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin.

Thanx on Friday.

Toboggans in the snow.

Mr. Anderson is still suffering from the effects of the tragic accident of last week.

Misses Hardisty and Anderson were seen some time earlier driving on Friday Night.

Red River Lode has almost certainly been saved from further attack of that sinister fever.

Less than a mile of Red River is expected to be covered before being up settlers for the Red Deer country.

The Indians made a very poor hunt during January as the weather was cold, and the crops prospects were not good.

Owing to the increase use of coal, however, has been hampered in farm duties, the present thus in any previous year.

J. Hutton returned from a trading trip to Batoche on Friday of last week. The snow is very deep and the conditions very bad.

X. St. John has dug well on his premises on Main street, striking water at a depth of about feet. About 100 feet below the brink of the high bank of the river, which is almost perpendicular at that point.

He went to T. G. Hutton's place, Little Mountain settlement, last week, at a depth of about 18 feet, but found nothing except a layer of sand immediately underneath a bed of gravel. A bucket full of the gravel which was washed out showed that there was no real being in the form of coarse gold. The well is to be progressed further.

LETHBRIDGE.

From the News.

The new town is looking up. Nearly all the outside work is done on it.

The ice has gone out this year, the depth of the river being good. On the river have the ice still remains and teams are still crossing on it, but it is getting thinner.

The Dominion Government will send an official to the Northwest in the spring to examine the claims of those half breeds who are now engaged in fighting the Commissioner.

A meeting will be held in the railway waiting room at Lethbridge, next Friday for the purpose of organizing a rifle association at Lethbridge.

A number of young men have been gathering at the corner of Main and Main streets, playing cards and shooting guns.

Mr. Nelson brought into our office today some live native grasshoppers, which he had captured in the field with them. This shows what kind of weather we have in this part of the country. We speak seriously for it as a fact.

REGINA.

From the Leader.

Mr. Ponson has gone out to take the building materials for the bridge to be built across the Qu'Appelle River.

Capt. Parsons mill at Moose Mountain is now nearly completed and will be a great addition to the city there.

We call attention to a circular of the P. R. Co. barley. It shows that there will be a good market for barley next year.

Railway officials are anxious to change the location of the station house so that the members of the Board of Police Commissioners may be able to get there without difficulty.

Mr. Macdonald paid Regina a visit on Tuesday. He explained the wants and wishes of the Crooked Lake Indians, to His Honour the Lieutenant Governor.

Mr. Neale arrived here on Thursday night and was placed under arrest by Col. Irvine for the alleged beating of his wife. He was at once sent back to his mission. Capt. Neale claims when placed under arrest by orders of Col. Irvine he was told that he would be charged with assault and battery, but was never granted him the desired leave of absence.

The affair has created some sensation here.

A HERO.

He holds his life as a trust, and not as a possession. His general course of action is that of a administrator, rather than that of an owner.

He thinks little about himself, but much about others. The ordinary man would have let go out of his life, but what can he do with it.

It promotes or hinders, or weakens, confidence in his capacity to manage his affairs. To serve because he looks out on life from the standpoint of the least Christ-like hero wrote:

"I am not my own."

He was born at Mataura, Ceylon, educated for its diamonds, and on Mr. Lawrence's return he went with him.

She asked if she had brought any with her.

"Yes," and the mother, producing her baby, "here's my Mataura diamond."

She was prophetic, though in words, which were not heard by the child, but which were spoken by the child, which could not be heard by anyone else.

It was a boy and man. He never "found" anything, but always gave it away.

He was a man of estate, who had a hand to give, woman, child, or beast, to any creature that was down.

However, he was self-effacing, even at a great sacrifice, when self-sacrifice demanded by another's welfare. His father, a retailer, lived on a small income, and the family was obliged to make money at the ordinary where cadets prepared for the East India Service.

Foot-ball and cricket were as essential to an English boy's happiness as three meals a day. But Henry never indulged in these pastimes, and he would not ask his father for the money.

At the end of his vacation, the boy started home, collected a bundle of clothes for a poor lady in London. On arriving at the station, he bought a large one, thrown over the streets, and delivered it to her.

A sample deed. Yes, but one which stood at the head of the list, and which was not claimed to sell itself, but was carried by a bundle through London streets.

Now, with a few hundred and another thousand of Henry's, which had been sold, he had expanded his business.

A sheet of flame, a terrific report, and dense darkness were followed by his low voice saying, "I am here." I am here.

He lingered two days, his mind intent on serving till the last. Monday dinner was given to the garrison, and he joined the defence of the place, with the order "never to give in." He took the place when asked to retire, and ordered the gunners to blow up the bomb.

Here lies Henry Lawrence, who tried to do his duty. May the Lord have mercy on his soul.

JOB PRINTING

Of all descriptions done neatly, quickly and cheaply.

J. D. MAVEETY, PUBLISHER AND PROPRIETOR

3RD ST., PRINCE ALBERT, SASK
Communications.

Seed Grain

To the Editor of The Times.

The farming community has been largely interested in seed grain during the past season. The supply of seed grain to the settlers of this district by the Government has been very satisfactory, and the prices have been reasonable. The farmers have been pleased with the quality of the seed grain received, and have been able to plant their fields with good results.

The following are some of the seed grain suppliers:

1. Mr. Smith, 123 Main Street, Regina.
2. Mr. Johnson, 456 Main Street, Regina.
3. Mr. Brown, 789 Main Street, Regina.
4. Mr. Green, 1012 Main Street, Regina.
5. Mr. White, 1234 Main Street, Regina.

These suppliers have been able to offer competitive prices and high-quality seed grain to the farmers of this district.

Miss Mack & Co.

Mr. Breckman, the Italian Inspector left for Regina last week. While here he visited many farms and inspected various matters connected with his department, was generally well received. His arrangements for the coming season are very commendable, and doubtless he will be able to extend his services to the extent of his present position.
